sub_title: Masters Student at Delft University of Technology
summary: I am an Aerospace Engineer with experience in composite structure manufacturing, heat & mass transfer, and data analysis. I earned my Bachelor’s at UCSD in 2016 with additional master’s studies at TU Delft in 2018-19. My work experience includes manufacturing carbon fiber pressure vessels, designing the path for cryogenic propellant in an experimental rocket fuel pump, and performance analysis of pilot data from flight simulators.

awards.title: Eagle Scout Award
awards.description: I had the honor of earning the highest rank of scouting as a member of Troop 476. My Eagle Project was a renovation project at the Nature Center of my middle school to prepare it for demonstrations and tours of young students. The project totaled over 500 hours of labor spread over several weekends. After earning the rank of Eagle, I proceeded to also be awarded a Bronze Palm for continuing my participation in the Troop to teach the younger scouts.

profile_positions.description:
My primary job was to manufacture carbon fiber pressure vessels for pressure testing. These tests included both cyclic performance and burst pressure measurements. I was involved in every step from raw material to finished product, eventually executing the entire process independently. These were type IV pressure vessels, meaning a polymer liner was used as a mandrel and carbon fiber prepreg was applied via filament winding. I was also responsible for documenting the physical characteristics of each vessel and any notable events that happened during production. This info was recorded to possibly identify the reason for any performance outliers in our data.

My additional responsibilities included interpretation and analysis of X-Ray images of carbon fiber samples and optimizing software used for identifying weak points in the vessel. I used the X-Ray images to locate and measure areas of high porosity in the different layups. The software I optimized was used to locate the sources of sounds detected when fibers broke during testing. I reduced the runtime by roughly 80%. I am also a named applicant for a patent granted to our team for development of a component used in our filament winding process.
profile_positions.title: Engineering Intern

profile_positions.title: Masters Studies

profile_positions.description:
I joined the Flometrics team to create mathematical models of the prototype fuel pump. I built simulations in Matlab that would take into account the temperatures and pressures of our cryogenic fuels to determine the dimensions of parts of the pump. I performed experiments on the prototype to confirm my calculations. This model was then used to size the second version of the pump, which was an order of magnitude increase in thrust from the initial design. This project was funded by DARPA, and the attached video shows the pump in action.

I also worked on a calibration device for medical sensors, an artificial lung used to develop athlete testing equipment, a hydrogen gas tin accelerator, and many other projects. Working here was an amazing experience for me because of the huge variety of projects available for me to work on. I learned how to apply the theories taught to me during school, but importantly, became comfortable learning on the job. I was very unfamiliar with several key concepts whenever I started the projects, but became consistent at working through the roadblocks.
profile_positions.title: Aerospace Engineer

profile_positions.description: I worked to optimize the heat transfer in our liquid cooling units. I experimented with inserts to our heat sinks to improve the heat transfer from the water to the copper casings. The inserts were designed to cause turbulence in the water while flowing through the heat sink, increasing the heat transfer rate. I also performed calculations and experiments to determine the number of heat exchangers necessary for each unit.
profile_positions.title: Heat Transfer Engineer

company.name: University of California, San Diego - Jacobs School of Engineering

profile_positions.company: UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering
profile_positions.description: For my final Bachelor's project, I worked on a team of 10 to experiment with new liquid rocket propellants. We used a bi-propellant pump with an LR-101 engine. I was in charge of the chemical analysis. I researched and predicted the effects of different additives to standard fuels. The final decision was to test a water-fuel emulsion. The experimental fuel consisted of 90% standard RP-1 and 10% water. Water was chosen for its high specific heat and volatility at combustion temperatures. The results of the experiment can be seen in the attached paper, and were presented by myself and Robert Bertino at the JANNAF Conference in November 2016.
profile_positions.title: Aerospace Engineer

profile_positions.description: Motion-Base Simulator Investigator - Fixed-wing transport aircraft at the stall point. Used the Vertical Motion Simulator at Ames to investigate the quality of alternative simulators for the instruction of pilots entering a stall. Determined mathematical model for mapping pilot reactions to various motion cues. Led pilots through experiment from briefing to conclusion. Developed data analysis to examine responses of pilots upon completion of all test flights.
profile_positions.title: VMS Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
Fixed-Base Simulator tester - HUD experiment for Blackhawk pilots. Researching multiple potential terrain and obstacle avoidance displays. Examined simulation for on-display errors. Provided comprehensive visual analysis for each flight by each pilot.

Motion-Base Simulator tester - Transfer of Training task for Fixed-wing transport aircraft. Piloted simulator to help develop motion gains on the flight model. Developed mathematical equations to map ramp in/out of the forcing functions.
profile_positions.title: Aerospace Research Intern
